subject: Google’s New Toys, Reddit’s Locked Doors, and Burning AI Empires
preview: Google giveth, Reddit taketh away, and your "listicle empire" may just hit the SERPOCALYPSE wall.                      Welcome to That's WasSERP issue Number Four.

full_threads.body:
Google giveth, Reddit taketh away, and your "listicle empire" may just hit the SERPOCALYPSE wall.
 
Welcome to That's WasSERP issue Number Four.

In the past week: Google quietly rolled out a "wild" trends tool you can't use, Reddit just put a huge padlock on the past, and if you doubt the existence of the shadow realm, ask this AI content farm Google once loved.

**


The Trends You Want, the Trends You Can't Have (Yet)

The new Google Trends can see the future down to the hour, the street, and probably what you're having for lunch.

But unless you happen to be a "developer or journalist" in Google's special circle, you'll still stay busy writing "What is [Topic]?" two days too late while someone in Google's alpha program is flooding the SERPs with fresh, hyper-targeted content because they saw the spike yesterday.

How to Fake It Till You Make It As You Wait

  • Stack tools: Combine Google Trends with every half-decent alternative you can find. Pretend you know what's coming next.
  • Crowdsource signals: Camp out on Reddit, Discord, and niche Facebook groups. Look for scraps of intel.
  • Move fast or die: If you can't publish within two hours of spotting a trend, Google "how to give up now", because the future looks fast.


**


Now You See Me, Now You're Dead: Google's AI Breakup Phase

The AI content playbook is simple: crank out text, rank fast, cash in. A certain site nailed it, and reportedly ranked for 700K+ keywords by May 2025.

June's core update loved the experiment, called it cute, then sent every URL with 100% AI probability and every ranking back to the basement.

The Takeaway

If your "content strategy" is ChatGPT + Ctrl+C + Ctrl+V, Google will let you peak long enough to taste the good life, then take it away just as you're busy buying new curtains.

Don't get it twisted, though. Google doesn't hate AI. In fact, it replaced your dominance in the SERPs with AI (😁). What it hates are low-effort listicle factories pumping out 800 words of nothing.

How Do You Survive the AI Content SERPocalypse?


  • Give Google a reason to commit: Original stats, expert takes, or insider info count for something.
  • Go niche-deep, not broad-shallow: Better to own 10 topics than skim 1,000.
  • Monitor the slow fades: Drops often start on long-tails before hitting head terms.


**


Has The Great Content Famine Begun?

Step one: Reddit pushes you to page two in the SERPs, then launches its own search engine.☑️

Step two: Reddit shuts the Wayback Machine.☑️

Step three: You're on your knees begging for forum scraps. [?]

It's not enough that Reddit is selling its live data to every AI company with a checkbook. Now it's locking away the dusty words of /01PanguyZ and others users, who unknowingly helped you:

  • Validate your half-baked startup pitch.
  • Find that niche keyword cluster no tool could surface.
  • Win that client by "predicting" a trend two months early.

Apparently, the Wayback Machine was kicked out of the chat group because of "AI scraper abuse." However, who would blame us if we overthink this?

It's increasingly looking like the internet's original business model, aka free and open access, was just a 30-year onboarding funnel.

Today, it's Reddit archives. Tomorrow it's:

  • Quora putting 2009 answers behind "Wisdom Plus"
  • YouTube transcripts locked in YouTube Premium Pro™
  • Wikipedia charging USD$10 per footnote click

Translation: Your content research may be living on borrowed time. Either start building your own archives now, or get ready to do "SEO" with nothing but a memory of what people used to talk about.

**

NO-BS Housekeeping Edition

This week's 60-second SEO chore: Rescue an Orphan Page

Orphan pages have zero internal links pointing to them. Google has a hate-hate relationship with them, so, here's a quick fix to give them a home and make Google love you again:

  1. Go to your sitemap or CMS and find a page with no internal links.
  2. Pick 2-3 relevant pages on your site.
  3. Add contextual links pointing to the orphan page. Best if you add them to the body text.
  4. Make sure the anchor text is descriptive, not "click here."
  5. Reindex those updated pages.

Just like that, you've given your page a new home and some serious ranking potential.


**


What We're Currently Reading

They said SEO died with Panda. They said it died with Penguin. They said it died with AI. Funny how it's still paying your rent: The Times SEO Died (and Came Back Better Than Ever)


Quote Of The Week

"We don't need a content strategy; we just write."

- And somehow you're surprised no one reads it.

And thus we wrap this week's SEO smoke signal. Interpret at your own risk. See you at Five.
